content.html: Accidentally I ran an interesting experiment comparing Twitter and Mastodon this morning when I tweeted/tooted about a blog post Mastodon: 3,000 followers (all from the last few days), 25 replies, 91 reblogs, 184 faves Twitter: 43,000 followers, 7 replies, 31 retweets, 183 likes
content.value:
Accidentally I ran an interesting experiment comparing Twitter and Mastodon this morning when I tweeted/tooted about a blog post

Mastodon: 3,000 followers (all from the last few days), 25 replies, 91 reblogs, 184 faves
Twitter: 43,000 followers, 7 replies, 31 retweets, 183 likes

photo.alt:
Post by me on Mastodon 9 hours ago:

I wrote about What to blog about: <link>

A big challenge with blogging is feeling the pressure to say something new and unique.

Two categories of content that completely skip that:
TILs (Today I Learned) about things you've just learned, and posts that describe projects you've just built.

So that's my advice for blogging: write about things you've learned, and write about things you've built!

My tweet 9 hours ago:

I wrote about "What to blog about" - how to avoid the pressure to try and say something unique and new, which can so often hold you back from publishing anything at all

TLDR: Write about things you've learned, and write about things you've built!
